Can Boeing trust SPEEA? That's a laugh. You've got it backward MB. The question really is, can SPEEA and the employees it represents trust Boeing? Scientists, engineers, physicists, chemists and technicians are people who, by virtue of their personality type, aren't militant or prone to striking. So the question is this. What's going on at Boeing that may cause those very people to walk off the job en mass and go on strike. Here's the answer. At a time when the company's business climate has probably never been better (new all-time records for orders, deliveries, revenue and profit almost every quarter), at a time when we literally can't build the airplanes fast enough and the company is showering the executives with massive bonuses and salary increases, they want to bend us over a barrel and rape us. Put the blame where it belongs MB, on Boeing Corporate and its overpaid executives, the very people who are directly responsible for the 787 being three years late and billions of dollars over-budget. I and an entire army of engineers tried repeatedly to tell them that their global outsourcing business model was fraught with enormous risk and had virtually no chance of success, but it's not what they wanted to hear so they ignored every warning they were given. They created this mess, now they can lie in it.

Yep. I couldn't have said it better myself. What there needs to be is a serious house cleaning at Boeing Corporate in Chicago, but I think we all know the chances of that happening are zero. Welcome to Corporate America.

Message.Title: safety board rules out excess voltage as the cause of a battery fire
Message.Msg: The National Transportation Safety Board has ruled out excess voltage as the cause of a battery fire on the Boeing 787 Dreamliner jet operated by Japan Airlines at Boston’s Logan Airport this month, the agency said on Sunday. Last week, governments across the world grounded the Dreamliner jet after a problem with a lithium-ion battery on a second 787 plane, flown by All Nippon Airways forced the jet to make an emergency landing in western Japan. The agency said in a statement forwarded by a Boeing Japan representative that examination of the flight recorder data from the JAL B-787 airplane indicated that the battery in the auxiliary power unit “did not exceed its designed voltage of 32 volts.”

Topic.Title: Why do liberals FEAR Ayn Rand?

Message.Msg: Most people who know anything about her don't fear her ideas. I suspect that most people who idealize her don't know much about her. The kinds of individual freedom she championed is the kind that encroaches on a lot of other people's freedom at one time, like the right of a wealthy person to build a large, unsafe building in the middle of the city, or the right of an individual to dump their factory waste into the river everyone uses. But then she came face to face with the fact that some problems are just too much for a person to absorb alone. She got cancer and realized how expensive that can be. Because of that, she took Social Security & Medicare. She had a choice, she could have said, if treatment is going to be that expensive, I just won't take treatment. But she did not. She took SS & Medicare to protect her wealth, just like almost everyone else would do. A lot of ideas are better in theory than in practice. Almost everyone wants their freedom at the expense of others' rights and freedoms.

The battery charge electronics is made by Securaplane (Tuscon, Arizona), not Thales. Thales is the power storage subsystem integrator. The FAA made the announcement that the "battery did not exceed its designed voltage of 32 volts" - according to the downloaded data from the flight recorder. The issue for the safety of the battery is not only the total voltage being applied by the charger (in this case 32 Volts) but also the charge voltage at the individual cell level which must not exceed its rated amount, for the GP Yuasa cell that is 3.7 Vdc, otherwise the cell will fail and potentially burn up and explode. Like any battery, the cells are in a series string to create, in this case, the near 30 volt capability. The internet photo of the failed pack shows 8 cells (3.7 x 8 = 29.6). If the charge voltage for the pack is 32, then the individual cell charge is 32/8 = 4 volts, less some amount of loss. Let's say that each cell is supposed to see no more than .2 volts above its rated performance as well as not exceed a particular charge rate. (You have to apply a slightly higher voltage to a cell than its voltage state in order to push the charge into it - and then stop at the rated limit.) The charger must perform "balance charging" which means that the charger monitors the voltage of each cell in a pack and varies the charge on a per-cell basis so that all cells are brought to the same voltage. Not all cells are "alike" and their charge profiles are slightly different, meaning that the cells could get substantially "out of balance" relative to each other and a cell (or cells) might begin to see charge voltages in excess of their rating. Say, anyone of those cells "shorts" (a common failure mechanism), then the applied voltage to the remaining cells could, without individual or smart control, increase by the proportion of the lost cell to the pack. So, now we are talking about (8 x 3.9)/7 - 3.9 = .56Vdc over the nominal applied to each cell. Lead acid and Ni-Cad batteries would not care, but it may be enough to begin a catastrophic sequence of collateral cell failures over time for a Lithium-Ion battery. Each individual cell must have protection against collateral overvoltage - not just at the pack level. That is the job of the electronics that may be embedded in each cell along with the Securaplane charger. Securaplane claims that their charger keeps track of cell imbalance as well as other faults. But I was amused that Securaplane said as of today that they were not yet "involved" in the investigation. They should have been involved from day one. The Securaplane design needs to be gone over with a "fine tooth comb" by experts outside of Boeing's plane division and Securaplane. Boeing has folks in El Segundo that have designed such chargers for Li-ion batteries for satellites. And, separately, the battery cells (in use) need to be tested for premature failure or degradation - which means that "good" batteries of similar operational use and the same and different lots need to be examined. Further, since the other failure driver is being over-loaded (too high of a discharge rate), Boeing needs to do "use case" analyses to determine whether there is unanticipated high load conditions and how those are mitigated.

Message.Title: NTSB caving in to Boeing
Message.Msg: They will let Boeing do a cover up. So flyers will be on their own, at their own risk. Cessna was directed to replace their lithium batteries with either lead-acid or nickel-cadmium. The issue was a fire started when a ground power unit was plugged in when the battery was in a partially depleted charge state. The exact condition for the JAL battery fire. [[[A letter from Cessna to CJ4 owners after the incident cautioned: "Do not connect a ground power unit to the airplane if you have reason to believe the battery may be in a depleted state ... Do not leave the aircraft unattended with a ground power unit connected."}}} [[[ Boeing got regulators' permission to use lithium batteries in the jetliner in 2007, three years after U.S. passenger planes were barred from carrying non-rechargeable types as cargo because of their flammability.]]]

Here's the short, simplified answer (the details are much more complex). Boeing wants to stop offering the pension to new hires. What's to not like you're thinking. If you're a current employee, it doesn't affect you. Oh yes it does. There's a long, well documented history in this country of the process used by companies and corporations when they want out of the "pension business". Step 1 is to stop offering the pension to new employees. Step 2 is to FREEZE the pension for all existing employees. Sometimes there's also Step 3, which is to sell off the pension fund and the pension obligation to some insurance company somewhere who usually turns it into an annuity. If you want to put an important part of your retirement at risk, if you want to see it drastically reduced or possibly disappear completely, that's a sure fire way to do it. I know people that have had this happen to them and I've had a lot of experience with insurance companies (had to hire an attorney and sue the last one to get them to fulfill their obligation). I don't want my pension frozen and I don't want an insurance company, ANY insurance company, anywhere near my retirement. They cannot be trusted with anything, at any time, and the same is true of Boeing Corporate. If Boeing wants out of the "pension business", then they need to alleviate that concern by putting the necessary language in the contract so that existing employee's are protected from this very real threat. About that 401K Boeing wants to offer new hires in place of the pension ... Boeing's own calculations show that it's worth 33% less than the pension. SPEEA's calculations put the difference at 40%. Regardless of the number, that's a BIG reduction in benefits for a company that just recently gave its executives bonuses equal to their yearly salary (read that, hundreds of thousands if not millions of dollars per executive). Do you think Boeing's executives would agree to such a reduction in THEIR retirement? Bet not. There's a LOT more to what Boeing wanted to do to us, but SPEEA's negotiation teams finally got them to back off most of it. Still, the pension issue remains and I for one am not voting to put an important part of my retirement at risk. Now, if you want to lead by example, spin the Roulette wheel on your retirement and show us all how there's really nothing to be concerned about, show us all how a multi-national corporation like Boeing would never do such a thing to its employees (history strongly suggests otherwise by the way), by all means go ahead. We'll be watching, with great interest. Many of us, myself included, have worked for Boeing not years but decades and we know better. They have taught us well. And you? How long have you worked for Boeing? Thought so ...

Message.Title: A Call to Action
Message.Msg: This message is to all of the American workers that build the Boeing 787. Boeing workers are some of the smartest people in the American Work Force, weather you are a previous Rockwell, Mc Donnell Douglas or Hughes Aircraft employee. You can take pride in the products you have made. We have some of the smartest people in the industry working at Boeing. Yes there may be times when the employees and management don’t see eye to eye such as when negotiating for pay and benefits. But let me say that I speak for myself and many more of the Boeing workers that we will always produce our products so that our families and neighbors will always be proud of us. The attempt is always to make the best products that man is capable of making, and since many of these products are complicated to make, there will always be some hiccups here and there. But we are the American work force, and will always take pride in our work. Anyone wishing the Boeing Company harm will ultimately be disappointed. The workers at the Boeing Company will solve these issues, and most likely many more in the future. A proud Boeing Worker

Topic.Title: Boeing Reaches Endgame, Culmination Of Decade Of Problems With 'Nightmareliner'

Message.Msg: There are other things that are popping up, fuel line fitting, and others, But things may not be so sweet for Boeing investors. That’s because the learning curve effects that investors expected for the 787 are not happening as fast at Boeing has said. More specifically, UBS analyst, David Strauss believes it will take Boeing until 2021, rather than 2015 — as Boeing predicts – to breakeven on the 787, according to the New York Times. Boeing told that Times on December 10 that it “remains confident [that it will earn] low single digit” profit margins on the first 1,100 planes, which includes deliveries into 2021. Strauss calls foul on that. He thinks the 787 will lose between $4 billion and $5 billion on the 787 over the next three years or it will take until 2021 to start making a profit on the 787, if ever. While the basic model – the 787-8 lists for $206.8 million, Strauss estimates that Boeing is charging early customers about $116 million — it costs Boeing 400 million to produce each plane leaving it with a $300 million loss on each 787 it makes. Could Boeing achieve its far more ambitious profit targets? Not likely since the problems keep the plane from doing anythinbg except losing money for Boeing sharesholders.In the meantime, there is an important lesson here for strategists and investors — learning curve effects don’t magically happen. They have to be managed aggressively. And judging by the way Boeing Management has flubbed the 787 so far, and so far been able to prove does not have the management chops to fix the 787′s technical glitches and earn back its shareholder, customer and the public's trust

Message.Title: Boeing 787 memo and the Ford Pinto memo both fire starter deals for the passengers -
Message.Msg: According to a 1977 Mother Jones article by Mark Dowie, Ford allegedly was aware of the design flaw, refused to pay for a redesign, and decided it would be cheaper to pay off possible lawsuits. The magazine obtained a cost-benefit analysis that it said Ford had used to compare the cost of $11 repairs against the cost of settlements for deaths, injuries, and vehicle burnouts. The document became known as the Ford Pinto Memo.----[Boeing had to prove to the FAA that these batteries would never ignite as part of the 787 certification and if they did ignite they would not explode. Message.Msg: This is from the school web site: Special Police Officer Posted: August 10, 2012 Sidwell Friends School, a coeducational Quaker day school located in the Tenleytown area of Washington, DC, is seeking a full-time Special Police Officer. The ideal candidate will have above average computer skills and knowledge to assist security officers with security systems, reports on line, access control systems, video retention, camera surveillance and training of officers on maximum computer use for daily activities. Applicants must have a current SPO license; have the ability to pass criminal background checks & drug/alcohol testing. The ideal candidate will have the ability to write clear concise reports, prepare preliminary investigative reports, as well as interview witnesses, suspects & victims. This is a full-time hourly position which include free parking, lunch and an attractive benefits package, with retirement plan inclusive of employer match. Mail, fax, or email resume, information for three references and a copy of your current driver's & Special Police Officer licenses to: HR@sidwell.edu Who qualifies as a Special Police Officer in DC? Use DC for example. There are close to 4,000 private police officers currently. They work for security companies who do business with the metropolitan police dept. I believe the one wishing to obtain the license must perform similar training and tests that sworn officers do, such as weapons training, through the dc police. I'm fairly certain the DC license entitles you to carry a weapon and make arrests (provided you are doing so under federal, state, and local laws). But as I said, these rights and your jurisdiction vary from state to state, 10 of which do not govern private security companies at all. If you are actually attempting to receive a license, a private company is the way to go.

Message.Title: Lets get back to Boeing
Message.Msg: My pilot buddy who still works for a carrier I flew for and is a captain on the 777, and his wife who is a flight attendant told me the following. His buddies flying the 787 said it's the greatest plane they have ever flown. His wife who has flown as a flight attendant numerous times on the 787 said it's the best plane she has ever been on. Her comments were, #1 it is the smoothest plane in turbulance. #2 it takes off and climbs like your in an elevator. # 3 the passengers and crew love the 787. My buddy and his friends have mixed ideas on the battery problem. Bad battery, overcharging, charging malfunctions etc. The volt had a number of bad batteries. Could this be the same?? There are a lot of players in this game. The U.S., Japan, Boeing and China all have everything to lose if this problem is not solved soon. So what does this tell you? World wide they have the best minds working on this problem. It's only a matter of time and the 787 will fly again.

Message.Title: ‘Why me ?’ : Dealing with self-pity from a Buddhist perspective
Message.Msg: I mentioned in another thread that pity/self pity is a useless emotion and a gaggle of defenders of pity showed up. Apparently there are no other studiers of Eastern Philosophy than me on this board. Pity is condescending emotion that leads to negative consequences in one's life and thought patterns. Here is a Buddhist perspective on pity. There are also several books on the Russian philosopher G. I. Gurdjieff who established schools throughout the world that taught the way to a greater mind and higher consciousness should any of you be interested in freeing yourselves from your self imposed cave of victimization and darkness. "Bad things happening to good people, and good things happening to bad people can seem at times paradoxical for those of us who believe in some sort of a natural justice system that’s inbuilt in the way our universe works. After all, it might seem that the only reason for staying moral and righteous is to improve the odds that we encounter less of the undesirable things that constitute ‘suffering’. Only that, it dosen’t always work that way – suffering at times does not seem to discriminate between the good and bad, seemingly oblivious of a moral direction. Without doubt, bad undesirable things would happen to us, in ways that cannot be prevented : such is the nature of randomness of events that is an integral way of how the Universe works. Did the dinosaurs deserve to become extinct by a rogue asteroid (if indeed that’s why mass extinction happened), or did 6 million Jewish people deserve to be killed in the third Reich ? No logical explanation can override the fact, that many of our misfortunes are inevitably random, and no one’s fault. In Buddhism, this category of suffering is often called ‘suffering of suffering’ (1), an allusion to the element of inevitable misfortune at times that the very fact of our existence brings about. “Self-pity is easily the most destructive of the non-pharmaceutical narcotics; it is addictive, gives momentary pleasure and separates the victim from reality.” – John W Gardner One of the central goals of Buddhist practice is to deal with the problem of ‘suffering’ at the fundamental level of our awareness. There are two common routes : one is to adopt the hypothesis of Karma, in which every action of ours, conscious or unconscious, has a ripple effect that spans over multiple life-times, of one individual or many. The notion of Karma and re-birth was used by C. S. Jung to draw parallel to his theory of ‘archetypes’, a dynamic substrata of human experience in which humans are born into, thus giving rise to individual characteristics and psychological traits. (2) The source of these inherited archetypes arises in Jung’s view not from one’s personal Karma, but that from one’s ancestors. Karma in Jung’s view therefore does not have any super-natural elements of any re-incarnating element of human existence, but that of the effective of this ‘collective unconscious archetypes’ on our destinies. In this view therefore, our individual misfortunes and fortunes are just random ripples in a continued river of human consciousness, thus having no individual or personal significance. Our reaction should therefore logically be to counter such suffering with tolerance and forbearance, and make all efforts whenever possible to prevent recurrence of similar suffering to our future generations and also ourselves. In practice an operational understanding of Karma does not relieve suffering without a period of conditioning of our minds based on mindfulness and meditation, developing compassion for all living beings, whether they are more or less fortunate than ourselves. ‘Why me’ gets replaced by the broader concerns of ‘how can suffering be relieved for every being ?’ The second route is far more direct and philosophical, often based upon mystical traditions emphasized especially, but not exclusively, within esoteric teachings. The doctrine of emptiness (Diamond Sutra) for instance aims to replace the mundane concerns of existential suffering with a direct kind of happiness that arises out of an Unified sense of reality with the entire Cosmos, through a direct understanding of the inherently impermanent nature of events and things that we hold on to, to provide us with a false sense of stability and happiness. As the self itself is an impermanent entity, concerns for One’s self that bring unhappiness are perhaps way over-exaggerated. One should indeed work for one’s own welfare (as the Buddha emphasized) but in a manner that places spiritual concerns way before material concerns. One soon realizes that a lot of our suffering is brought about by attempting to cling on to things and states we crave for. ‘Why me ?’ is overshadowed by ‘How we are preventing ourselves from experiencing real happiness by excessive attachment to our petty concerns.’ Although Buddhism influenced psychotherapy is around for help, the Buddhist road to wisdom is essentially designed to be a journey we must experience for ourselves. Life is too short and evanescent for self-pity or continue to cling onto the bars of our psychological prison we impose by putting our own concerns above everybody else’s.

Message.Title: Dreamliner probe widens after excess battery voltage ruled out
Message.Msg: "The NTSB wanted to set the record straight," said one source familiar with the investigation who was not authorized to speak publicly. U.S. safety investigators on Sunday ruled out excess voltage as the cause of a battery fire last month on a Boeing Co 787 Dreamliner jet operated by Japan Airlines Co (JAL) and said they were expanding the probe to look at the system wide failure if true the planes will not fly for a long time and the loss in share value will be huge . U.S. investigators have already examined the lithium-ion battery that powered the APU, where the battery fire started in the JAL plane, as well as several other components removed from the airplane, including wire bundles and battery management circuit boards, the NTSB statement said. Aviation Week quoted Airbus programs chief Tom Williams as saying "failure management" was key and with Boeing’s failed management the shareholders of Boeing have some serious issues with stock price going down meanwhile EADS stock price has gone up over 27% over a year while Boeing shareholders have lost money the stock has been down for over a year now.( .69%)

That so called 50,000 hrs. was spread out over a number of test planes. That and fifty AP's now in service. its a drop in a bucket. Did you notice that this discrepancy didn't start occurring until passengers were using the AP's. Using the lighting and entertainment systems and recharging and using all their electronic devices?

Topic.Title: Dreamliner probe widens after excess battery voltage ruled out

Message.Msg: "U.S. investigators have already examined the lithium-ion battery that powered the APU, where the battery fire started in the JAL plane, as well as several other components removed from the airplane, including wire bundles and battery management circuit boards, the NTSB statement said." Having worked in the aerospace industry for 35+ years and having participated in hardware and system failure investigations (in this case for satellites) for in-orbit and on-ground failures, I find that it is highly unlikely that government "investigators" (bureaucrats) have arrived at any conclusion that is credible relative to the lithium-ion battery. Especially since the maker of the charge controller, Securaplane, today said that they were not yet involved in the investigation.
